channel.title: Designing for Reflection
channel.description: Design Components for the Design for Reflection in Interactive User Interfaces

wp:category.wp:cat_name: Temporal Perspective and Confrontation and Conversation Configurator

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Reflection is a crucial activity that enables individuals to gain insights and improve themselves. It is a valuable practice that is recognized across many fields. By reflecting, people can engage in various ways to comprehend and interpret things, become aware of their surroundings, and gain insights to make informed decisions for their well-being and advance societal values such as justice or environmental sustainability.

Human-centered interactionn was initially aimed at enhancing productivity. However, as the field of human-centered interaction progressed, researchers also began to incorporate emotions, experiences, and cultural characteristics. This led to the introduction of reflection as an important topic for consideration. Reflection offers three main benefits: it enhances education, improves the design process, and helps individuals gain greater self-knowledge. Despite its crucial role in human-centered interaction, there is still a need for a consistent definition of reflection

My goal is to intoduce design guidelines which aim to guide in designing for reflection. Design Approaches lead to Design Components which are all explained in detail.

item.title: Temporal Perspective
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Temporal Perspective

Temporal Perspectives involve integrating time-based information into interface design. This approach is commonly used in data tracking apps, where timelines are utilized to give users a clear overview of their gathered information.

Past

The past in Temporal Perspective feature aims to display historically tracked data in a way that allows users to reflect on how the data has changed over time and how different behaviors have contributed to the results. This can be implemented by using graphs to help users reflect on their health data over a certain period. These graphs classify the state of health and help users conclude the data

Many apps utilize graphs to assist users in reviewing their health data over a specific period. These graphs categorize health status and help users analyze the data. Recording several important health aspects is crucial to effectively monitoring improvements or declines in health.

Memory

The distinction between the past and memories as design resources is that the past is an objective representation of events, while memories are a subjective interpretation of the past. When aiming to evoke memories, users are shown specific events from their past and are prompted to evaluate their emotional state during that time or their overall satisfaction with their past selves.

Future

In the context of the future-oriented Temporal Perspective design approach, users are encouraged to contemplate their future and consider the implications of their actions. Apps that incorporate this approach use messages written by users to their future selves, as well as considerations of various life decisions and their anticipated outcomes. Apps can also offer a forecast function to showcase how the action might affect the user's future.

Slowness

Slowing down a process encourages users to reflect on their actions. This
can be applied to social media uploads and learning with prompts and questions.

Examples of possible Design Elements

Clockplot, Timeline, Calendaric views, Bar Plots.

A timeline can be used to display data from different time periods. This traditional method, when combined with bar plots, makes the data easier to understand compared to using values alone.

A calendar view can also display data from the previous month or year. It is best to utilize this feature with different colors representing various statuses of the days, e.g., showing days where the user ate well with a green color and days where the user didn't eat so well with a yellow or red color.

Clockplots can also be used in specific cases, but they are more complicated to understand and are best used to show data from the last 24 hours, for example.

Design Recommendation

Presented data should be narrowed down to the essential information.

Interactive approaches are more successful in supporting in reflection.

item.title: Confrontation
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Confrontation

Confrontation aims to trigger reflection by presenting things in a new light that can cause users to reflect. It involves gaining knowledge and comprehending the relationships between different pieces of information. Analyzing situations from various perspectives is essential to gaining a complete understanding.

Provocation

Reflection through discovery can be encouraged by confronting users with unpleasant information. For instance, predictions regarding an individuals health based on their consistent lifestyle can be provided to encourage reflection on their well-being.

Interpretation

By presenting data in a new light, users may rethink their behavior and come to new conclusions. This does not need to be implemented by provocing negative emotions; it can also be done by explaining how different behaviors affect other aspects of their lives differentlypositive or negative.

Examples of possible Design Elements

Predictions, Warnings, Giving Interpretations

Predictions can be utilized to support reflection. For instance, in this prototype, users were provided with a forecast before entering their food choices. This could prompt users to reconsider their choices when they see the direct consequences of their behavior.

Warnings work similarly to predictions but can also be used after the user has already entered data to show where the user needs to pay attention, e.g., to the high amount of carbohydrates added to the diet.

Another approach is to use interpretations. This method might be more challenging to implement because it involves integrating a substantial amount of data to interpret it successfully. Use cases for interpretations could include providing an explanation for why a user ate poorly on a certain day, such as tracking their bad mood, which may have led to cravings for sugary and fatty foods.

Design Recomendation

It's important to remember that focusing only on provoking users by pointing out their mistakes usually doesn't lead to good results. When designing for reflection, the main focus should always be on the user and their well-being. Therefore, it's best to keep users motivated by sandwiching the confrontation of negative information and results with positive reinforcement.

This was discovered in the qualitative study that intended to examine the app prototype. Users felt unmotivated and wanted to rather skip the step where they were possibly only confronted with negative results, especially when they knew that their behavior in terms of dietary wasn't great that day.

item.title: Conversation
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Conversation

A conversation can help users understand the importance of their experiences and put them into perspective. It can be a dialogue with the system or a genuine interaction with other users.

Conversation with the System

After manually tracking data, reminders, reflection prompts, and follow-up questions can be used to engage in a conversation with the system. Fitness and running apps, in particular, use follow-up questions after a tracked workout to inquire about the user's evaluation of the workout. Broad reflection questions can facilitate contemplation on a general topic, while specific questions can aid in directing attention to the learning process.

Conversation with real People

A conversational interface, e.g., Chatbots, is a user interface that allows users to communicate in a natural language, either by speaking or typing. It's important to carefully consider which features can be combined with the quantitative self-approach. Conversational interfaces, e.g. commentary features, can assist individuals in reviewing past behaviors and encouraging critical thinking through journaling. These interfaces are not fully utilized and are primarily used to provide information rather than collect data.

Examples of possible Design Elements

Reminders, Reflection-prompts, Follow-up Questions, Conversational Interfaces, Sharing data with friends and discussing them

Design Recommendation

Not everyone likes to receive comments on their data and progress, especially when they're not doing well. Users should have the option to disable the comment function and receive messages and answers to their data. While this might reduce the support for reflecting on their progress, the alternative could be that users feel embarrassed about their data and any comments they might receive, leading them to stop tracking their data on bad days.

item.title: Comparison
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Comparison

The comparison approach can prompt users to analyze their data by utilizing tools that facilitate data comparison, e.g., bar plots visualizing tracked data of different days or pie charts visualizing relationships of tracked data of different days.

Absolute Comparison

One way to support learning from one's experiences is by comparing actual and target values. For example, you can display the ideal daily water intake alongside the user's actual intake. Progress bars can be used to indicate how close the user is to meeting their goal.

Social Comparison

Social comparison involves comparing one's data with others, fostering competitive behavior. A leaderboard that shows who worked the best towards their goal can be utilized to introduce a competitive aspect, motivating individuals to reach their goals and avoid unhealthy behavior. Social comparison also aids individuals in evaluating their health status. Comparing current and past data is another method of making social comparisons, enabling users to track their progress and reflect on their daily experiences.

Examples of possible Design Elements

Pie charts provide a simple way for users to see the connection between their tracked data. In this prototype I used a pie chart to illustrate the relationship between three different micronutrients: fat, carbohydrates, and protein. While pie charts are not commonly used for comparing data, they were effective in this instance based on the findings of a qualitative study that looked at the prototype.

Stacked Bar Plots, Clustered Bar Plots, Dot Plots, Mosaic Plots, and Treemaps are great examples of conventional comparison visualizations. These visualizations can be used in almost every aspect of comparison. Bar Plots were here used to show the different steps and glucose levels on different days.

Design Recommendation

Social comparison doesn't work for everyone. This was discovered in a qualitative study that aimed to examine the app prototype. Participants mentioned feeling pressure to behave better, which could lead to them not tracking their data at all on days when they know they can't stick to their diet properly.

Therefore it should be always possible to individually decide whether they want to compare themselves to others or not, and in a privacy and data protection perspective, the users should always be informed that other users have insight on their tracked data.

item.title: Configurator
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Configurator

The four design components, i.e.,Temporal Perspective,Confrontation,Conversation, andComparison,can only be used separately in particular cases. When designing a prototype using these four design components, it became evident that certain combinations naturally fit together and are commonly used.

In the next section, you can select a commonly used design combination, view an example of it, and choose non-integrated design components to use with the existing design combination.

Temporal Perspective, Confrontation and Conversation

Configuration

Confrontation and Comparison

Configuration

Temporal Perspective and Confrontation

Configuration

Temporal Perspective and Comparison

Configuration

item.title: Background
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Background

Reflection

Reflection is an important activity that allows individuals to gain insights and improve themselves. It is a valuable practice recognized across many fields. Through reflection, people can engage in various ways to comprehend and interpret things, become aware of their surroundings, and gain insights to make informed decisions for their well-being and advance societal values such as justice or environmental sustainability.

Reflection is a tool for processing experiences, not a goal in itself. It promotes moral growth based on existing theories. Reflection can be described as an iterative process that involves moving back and forth between theory and practice.

Reflection in Human-Centered Design

Human-centered design aimes at improving productivity but has since evolved to include emotions, experiences, and cultural characteristics. This has led to the recognition of reflection as an important consideration, offering three main benefits: enhancing education, improving the design process, and aiding individuals in gaining greater self-knowledge. However, despite its crucial role, there is still a need for a consistent definition of reflection and a design guideline to adhere to while designing for reflection in human-centered design.

Gathering Information on Reflection: A Scoping Review is carried out

A scoping review was carried out to gather information about implementing reflection in a smartphone app and general applications.

The scoping review process closely follows the PRISMA checklist.

To begin the scoping review, research terms were created based on the specific information required to address the initial research question. Since this thesis focuses on reflection, the key search terms include reflection, self-tracking, and self-reflection. These terms help to focus the literature search on reflection-related topics. Additional search terms such as health data, health feedback, personal informatics, and personal health records were also included to narrow the literature search to health data.

To initiate the literature search, I chose and gathered pertinent papers that contain information on designing for reflection and how to support reflection in general. I combined search terms using the AND combination while searching in three chosen databases: ACM Digital Library, ScienceDirect, and IEEE Xplore. These databases were chosen for their excellent reputation in computer science research. To improve the accuracy of the search results, I applied several filters. I initially focused on literature written in English or German. Then, I narrowed it down to literature published in the last five years. To ensure a balanced distribution of information, I included only research articles in the selection. Finally, I arranged all the database results by relevance.

After conducting a thorough search in the ACM digital library and ScienceDirect database, I narrowed down the results to the top 200 most relevant articles about supporting reflection and designing for reflection. In the IEEE Xplore database, the number of resulting articles was already small enough that it didn't need to be limited.

After limiting the selection of literature, the abstracts were screened to narrow down the results. Only literature that provided insights on supporting reflection, visualizing health data, designing health apps, or developing apps that foster reflection was included.

The initially selected literature underwent full-text screening to exclude any irrelevant material. Both abstracts and full texts were assessed to determine why they should not be included in the scoping review. Some reasons for exclusion included papers that did not provide information on app design for visualizing health data, or did not offer guidance on implementing reflection support in user interfaces, or on supporting reflection in general.

The literature used for the scoping review can be found on OSF.

item.title: Temporal Perspective and Conversation
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Temporal Perspective, Conversation and Confrontation





In this prototype screen, three design approaches are integrated. The Temporal Perspective includes the Memory approach, allowing users to rate their day by choosing the appropriate emoji via the Likert scale. The Likert scale also serves as a conversation Approach, allowing users to converse with the system. To incorporate confrontation into the prototype, the user receives positive or negative feedback regarding their daily rating. This can motivate the user to maintain or improve their performance.

By adding the Comparison approach, users can now compare their daily ratings with those of another day, allowing them to reflect on why a particular day had a better or worse rating.

It is important to consider whether adding this information would be helpful or if it might overwhelm the user. Another downside is that the user could feel bad about the current day if it doesn't measure up to the previous day. It's better to focus on the present day without constantly comparing it to other days, which could make the user feel less positive about it.

item.title: Confrontation and Comparison
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Confrontation and Comparison





In this prototype screen, the Comparison and Confrontation features are incorporated. The Comparison feature displays a seven-day overview of another user alongside the user's own overview(social comparison) as well as the to be-reached target value (absolute comparison) that should be reached. This also offers a confrontation aspect since the user can see, how close to the value target the other users are and how much they missed this target in comparsion.

To enhance the prototype with conversation, a comment function has been added. This allows for gathering feedback from others, asking questions, and receiving helpful tips.

The main focus of this prototype screen was the comparison aspect. The Temporal Perspective approach didn't come across clearly to the participants of the qualitative study aimed at testing the prototype. To enhance the visibility of the Temporal Perspective approach, a graphical overview of macronutrients and caloric intake is now displayed.

The app now allows users to compare their data from the past seven days with another user's data. It also lets users have conversations with friends, which can be motivational and helpful for learning more about maintaining a healthy diet as a diabetes patient.

item.title: Hallo Welt!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Willkommen bei WordPress. Dies ist dein erster Beitrag. Bearbeite oder lsche ihn und beginne mit dem Schreiben!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hallo, dies ist ein Kommentar. Um mit dem Freischalten, Bearbeiten und Lschen von Kommentaren zu beginnen, besuche bitte die Kommentare-Ansicht im Dashboard. Die Avatare der Kommentatoren kommen von Gravatar.

item.title: Beispiel-Seite
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Dies ist eine Beispiel-Seite. Sie unterscheidet sich von Beitrgen, da sie stets an derselben Stelle bleibt und (bei den meisten Themes) in der Website-Navigation angezeigt wird. Die meisten starten mit einem Impressum, der Datenschutzerklrung oder einer beruns-Seite, um sich potenziellen Besuchern der Website vorzustellen. Dort knnte zum Beispiel stehen:

Hallo! Tagsber arbeite ich als Fahrradkurier, nachts bin ich ein aufstrebender Schauspieler und dies hier ist meine Website. Ich lebe in Berlin, habe einen groen Hund namens Jack, mag Piña Coladas, jedoch weniger (ohne Schirm) im Regen stehen gelassen zu werden.

...oder so etwas wie:

Das Unternehmen XYZ wurde 1971 gegrndet und versorgt die ffentlichkeit seither mit qualitativ hochwertigen Produkten. An seinem Standort in einer kleinen Grostadt beschftigt der Betrieb ber 2.000 Menschen und untersttzt die Stadtbewohner in vielfacher Hinsicht.

Als neuer WordPress-Benutzer solltest du dein Dashboard aufrufen, um diese Seite zu lschen und neue Seiten und Beitrge fr deine Website erstellen. Viel Spa!

item.title: Datenschutzerklrung
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Wer wir sind

Textvorschlag: Die Adresse unserer Website ist: http://localhost.

Kommentare

Textvorschlag: Wenn Besucher Kommentare auf der Website schreiben, sammeln wir die Daten, die im Kommentar-Formular angezeigt werden, auerdem die IP-Adresse des Besuchers und den User-Agent-String (damit wird der Browser identifiziert), um die Erkennung von Spam zu untersttzen.

Aus deiner E-Mail-Adresse kann eine anonymisierte Zeichenfolge erstellt (auch Hash genannt) und dem Gravatar-Dienst bergeben werden, um zu prfen, ob du diesen benutzt. Die Datenschutzerklrung des Gravatar-Dienstes findest du hier: https://automattic.com/privacy/. Nachdem dein Kommentar freigegeben wurde, ist dein Profilbild ffentlich im Kontext deines Kommentars sichtbar.

Medien

Textvorschlag: Wenn du ein registrierter Benutzer bist und Fotos auf diese Website ldst, solltest du vermeiden, Fotos mit einem EXIF-GPS-Standort hochzuladen. Besucher dieser Website knnten Fotos, die auf dieser Website gespeichert sind, herunterladen und deren Standort-Informationen extrahieren.

Cookies

Textvorschlag: Wenn du einen Kommentar auf unserer Website schreibst, kann das eine Einwilligung sein, deinen Namen, E-Mail-Adresse und Website in Cookies zu speichern. Dies ist eine Komfortfunktion, damit du nicht, wenn du einen weiteren Kommentar schreibst, all diese Daten erneut eingeben musst. Diese Cookies werden ein Jahr lang gespeichert.

Falls du ein Konto hast und dich auf dieser Website anmeldest, werden wir ein temporres Cookie setzen, um festzustellen, ob dein Browser Cookies akzeptiert. Dieses Cookie enthlt keine personenbezogenen Daten und wird verworfen, wenn du deinen Browser schliet.

Wenn du dich anmeldest, werden wir einige Cookies einrichten, um deine Anmeldeinformationen und Anzeigeoptionen zu speichern. Anmelde-Cookies verfallen nach zwei Tagen und Cookies fr die Anzeigeoptionen nach einem Jahr. Falls du bei der Anmeldung Angemeldet bleiben auswhlst, wird deine Anmeldung zwei Wochen lang aufrechterhalten. Mit der Abmeldung aus deinem Konto werden die Anmelde-Cookies gelscht.

Wenn du einen Artikel bearbeitest oder verffentlichst, wird ein zustzlicher Cookie in deinem Browser gespeichert. Dieser Cookie enthlt keine personenbezogenen Daten und verweist nur auf die Beitrags-ID des Artikels, den du gerade bearbeitet hast. Der Cookie verfllt nach einem Tag.

Eingebettete Inhalte von anderen Websites

Textvorschlag: Beitrge auf dieser Website knnen eingebettete Inhalte beinhalten (z.B. Videos, Bilder, Beitrge etc.). Eingebettete Inhalte von anderen Websites verhalten sich exakt so, als ob der Besucher die andere Website besucht htte.

Diese Websites knnen Daten ber dich sammeln, Cookies benutzen, zustzliche Tracking-Dienste von Dritten einbetten und deine Interaktion mit diesem eingebetteten Inhalt aufzeichnen, inklusive deiner Interaktion mit dem eingebetteten Inhalt, falls du ein Konto hast und auf dieser Website angemeldet bist.

Mit wem wir deine Daten teilen

Textvorschlag: Wenn du eine Zurcksetzung des Passworts beantragst, wird deine IP-Adresse in der E-Mail zur Zurcksetzung enthalten sein.

Wie lange wir deine Daten speichern

Textvorschlag: Wenn du einen Kommentar schreibst, wird dieser inklusive Metadaten zeitlich unbegrenzt gespeichert. Auf diese Art knnen wir Folgekommentare automatisch erkennen und freigeben, anstatt sie in einer Moderations-Warteschlange festzuhalten.

Fr Benutzer, die sich auf unserer Website registrieren, speichern wir zustzlich die persnlichen Informationen, die sie in ihren Benutzerprofilen angeben. Alle Benutzer knnen jederzeit ihre persnlichen Informationen einsehen, verndern oder lschen (der Benutzername kann nicht verndert werden). Administratoren der Website knnen diese Informationen ebenfalls einsehen und verndern.

Welche Rechte du an deinen Daten hast

Textvorschlag: Wenn du ein Konto auf dieser Website besitzt oder Kommentare geschrieben hast, kannst du einen Export deiner personenbezogenen Daten bei uns anfordern, inklusive aller Daten, die du uns mitgeteilt hast. Darber hinaus kannst du die Lschung aller personenbezogenen Daten, die wir von dir gespeichert haben, anfordern. Dies umfasst nicht die Daten, die wir aufgrund administrativer, rechtlicher oder sicherheitsrelevanter Notwendigkeiten aufbewahren mssen.

Wohin deine Daten gesendet werden

Textvorschlag: Besucher-Kommentare knnten von einem automatisierten Dienst zur Spam-Erkennung untersucht werden.

item.title: Blog-Startseite
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Reflecting on our actions is vital for learning from our mistakes, recognizing our strengths and weaknesses, and developing self-confidence. Reflecting on health data can also assist users in making better choices by helping them learn from previous mistakes and identifying weaknesses. This is why incorporating reflection is crucial when designing user interfaces, especially for those intended to support health-related contexts.

Since the number of people in need of health support is rising due to increasing obesity rates and related health issues. Therefore, it is more important than ever to invest in platforms that promote a healthier lifestyle and help people stay motivated to achieve their goals.

Today, technologies such as smartphones and wearables make it easier than ever to track personal health data. This enables users to gain insight into their daily movement, heart rate, and blood pressure. Medical researchers can also use this data to aid in recovery or assess disease progression. However, simply collecting data is not enough for users to determine their overall health. For example, looking at the number of steps taken during the day alone doesn't provide meaningful insights. When compared to past steps, heart rate, and blood pressure, it becomes possible to conclude whether ones health status is improving or deteriorating. The way this data is presented is crucial in guiding users to draw conclusions and reflect on their health.

The research on designing for reflection is still in its early stages, and there is much work still to be done. There is no clear guideline yet on how to design for reflection. This work aimed to further investigate designing for reflection and to demonstrate some possibilities that could be used in the design process to incorporate reflection.

After carrying out a scoping review to investigate designing for reflection, it became clear, that designing for reflection can be divided into four design components (Temporal Perspective, Conversation, Comparison and Confrontation). The scoping review method and results can be found in the chapter Background.

Each of these design components aims to encourage reflection in the user in different ways. This page is intended to explain these four design components and demonstrate how they can either be combined or cannot be combined to make the design for reflection more successful. It can guide the design process and illustrate how reflection can be incorporated by displaying use cases based on a design prototype for diabetes patients.

Temporal Perspective

Showing data of different time spans, giving forecasts, or letting the user remeber things from the past.

Users can write diaries at the end of each day to reflect on the experiences they made.

More information

Conversation

Giving the user opportunities to conversate with the app or with real people.

With a commentary feature users can exchange experiences or motivate each other.

More information

Comparison

Comparing the tracked data with a goal or with data of other people leads.

Comparing data with data of a friend can lead in competitive behavior and motivate.

More information

Confrontation

Confront users with new information or present information in a new light.

Giving the user forecasts on how their behavior will impact their future or showing the user their mistakes.

More information

Every design components should be used with care. It is important to plan beforehand the desired results and how users can be supported in reaching their goals e.g. losing weight, being more active or having a more stable blood sugar over the day. Utilizing reflection should be an additional step to further support users in their process of reaching their goals. It is also important to keep in mind that some aspects of designing for reflection can have a negative impact on users e.g. getting too much negative feedback with the confrontation design component. Therefore, it is important to give users the freedom to enable or disable this feature, so they won't get demotivated when they are not able to keep track of their goal.

item.title: Header
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Designing for Reflection in Interactive User Interfaces

item.title: Categories
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Designing for reflection can be categrized into four main design approaches that aid in supporting and stimulating reflection when using interactive user interfaces.

Temporal Perspective

Temporal perspectives refer to incorporating temporal information into interface design.

Conversation

A conversation can help users understand the significance of their experiences and quantify them.

Discovery

The Discovery approach aims to prompt users to reflect by presenting things in a new light.

Comparison

The comparison approach can encourage users to reflect on their data by using features that aid in data comparison.

item.title: Temporal Perspective and Conversation
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: <!-- wp:categories {"metadata":{"name":"Configurate"}} /-->

item.title: Temporal Perspective and Confrontation
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Temporal Perspective, and Confrontation





The Temporal Perspective approach provides users with foresight into the future, while the Confrontation aspect informs users about the potential negative impact of their food choice.

The addition of Conversation in this prototype screen allows users to explain their food choices. This can be useful for reflecting on their decisions later on, but may feel too critical when making the choice. Users should not feel pressured by the app and be able to use it easily without feeling annoyed by any expectations.

When using the Comparison approach, users now have access to additional information about the amount of insulin they needed to take at the same time the day before. This can prompt them to reconsider their food choices and possibly opt for foods that had a lesser impact on their glucose levels the previous day. On the other hand, it could also lead them to rationalize their current food choices, especially if they had eaten even less healthy food the day before.

The prototype enables users to justify their food choices and view their dietary performance from the preceding day. However, this may place excessive information and expectations on the user, potentially leading to decreased food tracking when the food choice would significantly impact their glucose levels.

The prototype's main goal is to help users make better dietary choices by providing information on both good and bad food options. Users won't be well supported in this goal if they avoid tracking their food.

item.title: Temporal Perspective and Comparison
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Temporal Perspective and Comparison





This screen allows the user to compare data over seven days. It displays two barplots in one graph, showing the blood glucose level and macronutrients. The macronutrient bar is divided into three separate bars for carbohydrates, fat, and protein. Specifically, the carbohydrate bar is positioned at the bottom for the most effective comparison, as carbohydrates are the most important macronutrient for diabetes patients.

Adding conversation to the prototype screen doesn't necessarily have to involve people chatting or talking to each other. It can also involve giving users the option to share the data with others. This was achieved by adding a share button in the top right corner. Users can choose whether they want to share their progress with their friends on another app, even if their friends are not using the app. This provides users with a lot of freedom, and by deciding whether to share their data, they are prompted to reflect on the data they have tracked and whether it's worth sharing.

With the addition of Confrontation, the user can now obtain information on which food was particularly good and which was particularly bad. This is intended to assist the user in gaining knowledge to improve their diet.

The new features enable users to share their data and receive feedback from the app on the quality of the food in their diet. Users can now also share the specific good and bad foods they consumed on a particular day.
